awd_titl_txt: Graduate Student Travel Support Request for the IFAC Conference on Cyber-Physical & Human Systems 2018
awd_abstract_narration:
This proposal is for support of student travel for the 2nd International Federation of Automatic Control (IFAC) Conference on Cyber-Physical and Human Systems being held in Miami, Florida.   The conference is sponsored by the Institute of Electrical and Electronic Engineers.  The focus on integration of Human and Cyber-Physical Systems is an area of great importance and direct applicability to NSF's Cyber-Physical Systems and Smart and Connected Communities Programs.   The award will provide travel support for approximately 10 graduate students to attend, present papers, and participate in conference activities.
  
This conference will provide the students with the opportunity to attend presentations of cutting-edge research results representing the state-of-the-art in cyber physical systems and their integration with humans.   The attendees are offered a diversity of interactive forums, technical sessions, targeted workshops, interesting poster sessions, and exciting demonstrations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
Considering ever-increasing advances in cyber-physical systems, the traditional boundaries between humans and technology are becoming uncertain; hence, the complex relationship between humans and technology must be studied from engineering, human factors, and social sciences perspectives.

To this end, the second IFAC Conference on Cyber-Physical & Human Systems was held in Miami, Florida, United States (December 14-15, 2018) that brought together researchers and practitioners from academia and industry to exchange of ideas, methods, and results from multiple disciplines including, for example, engineering, computer science, sociology, and psychology with an overarching aim of understanding the interactions between cyber-physical systems and humans.

CPHS 2018 made a significant contribution to the goal of breaking down the silos that separate disciplines and creating a meeting venue to cultivate innovation and collaboration. The conference received 107 submissions, of which 81 were accepted, resulting in a 76% acceptance rate. There were a total of 141 registrations with 34 students. Among the 16 countries represented in the conference, the highest number of registrations came from US (80), France (18), Germany (13) and Japan (13). There were two parallel tracks of oral sessions on each day and a poster session at the end of the first day.

In this highly interdisciplinary and exploratory field, this NSF grant supported students, where these students had the opportunity to (1) receive the direct benefit of obtaining new scientific and engineering knowledge, (2) acquire this field’s important problems and research themes at the very beginning of their careers, and (3) establish worldwide contacts with the researchers and practitioners in control systems, automation, cognitive sciences, economics, sociology, and anthropology.


Last Modified: 01/30/2020
Modified by: Tansel Yucelen
por.por_txt_cntn:
Considering ever-increasing advances in cyber-physical systems, the  traditional boundaries between humans and technology are becoming  uncertain; hence, the complex relationship between humans and technology  must be studied from engineering, human factors, and social sciences  perspectives. 
 
 To this end, the second IFAC Conference on Cyber-Physical & Human  Systems was held in Miami, Florida, United States (December 14-15, 2018)  that brought together researchers and practitioners from academia and  industry to exchange of ideas, methods, and results from multiple  disciplines including, for example, engineering, computer science,  sociology, and psychology with an overarching aim of understanding the  interactions between cyber-physical systems and humans. 
 
 CPHS 2018 made a significant contribution to the goal of breaking down  the silos that separate disciplines and creating a meeting venue to  cultivate innovation and collaboration. The conference received 107  submissions, of which 81 were accepted, resulting in a 76% acceptance  rate. There were a total of 141 registrations with 34 students. Among  the 16 countries represented in the conference, the highest number of  registrations came from US (80), France (18), Germany (13) and Japan  (13). There were two parallel tracks of oral sessions on each day and a  poster session at the end of the first day. 
 
 In this highly interdisciplinary and exploratory field, this NSF grant  supported students, where these students had the opportunity to (1)  receive the direct benefit of obtaining new scientific and engineering  knowledge, (2) acquire this field’s important problems and research  themes at the very beginning of their careers, and (3) establish  worldwide contacts with the researchers and practitioners in control  systems, automation, cognitive sciences, economics, sociology, and  anthropology.
